design.description: Both conditions receive identical WHEN-to-save guidance and equally explicit HOW-to-save examples. Vagueness comes from scenarios (user requests), not system prompts.
design.nl_format: Natural English (e.g., 'I'll save X to the codebase category')

conditions.nl: Natural language intent via [SAVE: category] tags
conditions.structured: Structured tool call via save-memory command

scenario_level_analysis.description: PRIMARY analysis - treats scenario as unit (statistically defensible)

trial_level_comparison.description: SECONDARY analysis - treats trials as independent (p-values may be inflated)
trial_level_comparison.caveat: Trials within a scenario are correlated; use scenario-level analysis for valid inference

comparisons.reason: AB: Content A accurately captures the user's statement without adding information, while Content B adds "main application file" which was not stated by the user and is a hallucination. | BA: Content B accurately captures exactly what the user said without adding assumptions, while Content A adds "main application file" which was not stated in the original message and constitutes hallucination.
comparisons.structured_content: <save-memory category="codebase">The main application file app.ts is located in ./src directory</save-memory>

comparisons.reason: AB: Content A accurately captures the user's statement without adding information (like "Main application file") that wasn't in the original message, while Content B hallucinated that app.ts is the "main application file" when the user only stated its location. | BA: Content A adds the assumption that app.ts is the "Main application file" which was not stated in the original message - the user only specified the location, not the file's purpose.
comparisons.structured_content: <save-memory category="codebase">Main application file app.ts is located in ./src directory</save-memory>
